description: Borrowed from German Marzipan, from Italian marzapane, Venetian marzapane. Believed to be, with influence from pane (“bread”), derived from Arabic مَرْطَبَان‎ (marṭabān, “spice box”) which comes from the name of a Burmese port known for its spice exports, Martaban, now called in Burmese မုတ္ထမ (muthta.ma.).

entries.meaning: A confection made from a paste of almonds, sugar and egg white as a binder.
A similar confection made using another nut, such as peanut or hazelnut.
examples: Place the hazelnuts on a baking sheet and grill  […]  then grind finely  […]  then add the caster sugar and ground hazelnuts [to egg whites] and mix to a stiff marzipan paste. Sandwich the pecan nuts together in pairs with a little of the hazelnut marzipan.

entries.meaning: (countable) A piece of such a confection.

verbs.description: marzipan (third-person singular simple present marzipans, present participle marzipanning, simple past and past participle marzipanned)
